name: winafpi

stmt.origin: mp2an(wceq(cfv(cale, c0), c0), wcel(c0, cwina), wne(c0, com))
stmt.pretty: mp2an((aleph ` c0)= c0, c0 ∈ InaccW, c0 ≠ _om)

body.origin:
|- wceq(cfv(cale, c0), c0)
-| wcel(c0, cwina)
-| wne(c0, com)
-| wi(wa(wcel(c0, cwina), wne(c0, com)), wceq(cfv(cale, c0), c0))
body.pretty:
⊢ (aleph ` c0)= c0
⊣ c0 ∈ InaccW
⊣ c0 ≠ _om
⊣ ((c0 ∈ InaccW ∧ c0 ≠ _om)→(aleph ` c0)= c0)

cumulated.origin:
|- wceq(cfv(cale, c0), c0)
-| wcel(c0, cwina)
-| wne(c0, com)
-| wi(wa(wcel(c0, cwina), wne(c0, com)), wceq(cfv(cale, c0), c0))
cumulated.pretty:
⊢ (aleph ` c0)= c0
⊣ c0 ∈ InaccW
⊣ c0 ≠ _om
⊣ ((c0 ∈ InaccW ∧ c0 ≠ _om)→(aleph ` c0)= c0)

body.origin: |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, cwina), wne(c0, com)), wceq(cfv(cale, c0), c0))

cumulated.origin:
|- wceq(cfv(cale, c0), c0)
-| wcel(c0, cwina)
-| wne(c0, com)

comment: This theorem, which states that a nontrivial inaccessible cardinal is its own aleph number, is stated here in inference form, where the assumptions are in the hypotheses rather than an antecedent. Often, we use ~ dedth to turn this type of statement into the closed form statement ~ winafp , but in this case, since it is consistent with ZFC that there are no nontrivial inaccessible cardinals, it is not possible to prove ~ winafp using this theorem and ~ dedth , in ZFC. (You can prove this if you use ~ ax-groth , though.) (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 28-May-2014.)
